There isn't an organic way to grow food and a conventional way to grow food.
There are many ways to grow food, some of which can be considered organic, and all of which can be labeled conventional.
Modern organic agriculture is defined by restrictions on inputs, typically mandates that natural inputs be used.
Synthetic fertilizers and pesticides (including insecticides, herbicides, and fungicides) are prohibited, as are genetically modified crops.
Beyond that, the organic standards vary from country to country.
(Organic pioneers like Sir Albert Howard tended to be more focused on soil health than the exclusion of synthetics, but times have changed.)
The limitations on fertilizers and pesticides encourage organic farmers to use some really good practices, like planting cover crops.
Of course, these practices are available to conventional farmers, and indeed many conventional farmers do plant cover crops.
However, the incentives for doing so tend to be weaker for conventional farmers when "synthetic" approaches exist.
There's plenty of variety within organic agriculture, too.
Some will be concerned with the carbon emissions from trucking in huge volumes of compost, whereas others may not care.
Some will use organic pesticides more liberally than others.
There are also some cool things that are only available to conventional farmers.
For instance, precision fertilizer application allows farmers to get the improved yields of synthetic fertilizers while reducing fertilizer pollution.
This allows for food to be grown on less land, which is a big deal.
Organic won't allow this because it doesn't like synthetic fertilizers.
Speaking of which, organic agriculture is dependent on synthetic fertilizers.
Yeah, I know that I just said that organic "doesn't like synthetic fertilizers," but there's a loophole: animals can turn natural fertilizers into synthetic fertilizers.
The situation in the US is particularly egregious.
USDA organic standards allow manure from conventionally-raised animals.
That means you can grow conventional corn with synthetic fertilizer, feed it to a cow, and then use the cow's manure to fertilize organic crops.
The point that deserves to be emphasized here is that farm animals don't make elemental nutrients or fix nitrogen.
The nutrients in animal manure come from whatever the farm animal has eaten.
In effect, this makes animals a vehicle for laundering nutrients.
They turn grains grown with synthetic fertilizers into all-natural, certifiably organic manure.
Some organic standards, like those in the European Union, are a bit more stringent.
EU organic standards don't allow manure from conventional animals.
However, there are other organic fertilizers, and research has found that organic farms in France have significant dependence on nutrients from conventional agriculture.
I don't mean to come down too hard on organic here, because reusing nutrients that are waste products of conventional agriculture tends to be a good thing.
We have to do something with all of that manure, and we also need to fertilize crops somehow.
(However, we also shouldn't pretend that organic fertilizers are completely harmless.
They, too, contribute to pollution .)
I mention the dependence of modern organic agriculture on conventional agriculture because we need to be careful about prescribing organic as a solution for the whole world.
If organic today is dependent on conventional agriculture, then where would organic be in a world without conventional?
Some organic advocates like to suggest that synthetic fertilizer was developed as a way to put explosive factories to use after World War II.
It's true that explosives and nitrogen fertilizer both depend on fixation of nitrogen via the Haber-Bosch process.
It's also true that World War II increased the world capacity for nitrogen fixation via Haber-Bosch, and that the end of the war meant that that capacity could be diverted from bombs to fertilizer.
Even so, some amount of synthetic nitrogen was actually needed.
The foods we eat contain lots of nitrogen-rich molecules (like proteins, DNA, and RNA), and all of that nitrogen has to come from somewhere.

The British scientist William Crookes gave a speech in 1898 -- before the discovery of the Haber-Bosch process -- pointing to the eventual insufficiency of "natural" sources of nitrogen for feeding the world's population.
Synthetic nitrogen is needed today, and it will continue to be needed for quite some time.
In his excellent tome on nitrogen fertilizer, Enriching the Earth , Vaclav Smil considers the use of synthetic nitrogen in the United States and China.
He concludes that the US could conceivably do without synthetic nitrogen by improving agricultural practices, moderating consumption of animal foods, and reducing food exports.
However, he argues that China, with its high population density and relatively low consumption of animal foods, is existentially dependent on nitrogen fertilizer.
(Yes, China can probably reduce its nitrogen fertilizer usage , which is inflated by government subsidies, but doing without it altogether is unlikely .)
And that brings me to what I think is my most important point.
Whatever you choose to buy, please recognize that your choice isn't likely to be a solution on a global, national, or even local scale.
In the grocery store, we are often faced with the choice of organic versus conventional.
We shouldn't let that choice define the debate about how food should be grown.
Some people like to advocate for a "best of both worlds" approach, but I dislike this framing.
For one, those worlds are not so separate.
More importantly, I'd rather not even be talking about organic and conventional, and I particularly prefer not to define solutions in terms of these categories.
Roughly speaking, conventional farmers have incentive to do what's profitable over some time frame, whereas the main governing principle of modern organic is avoiding synthetics.
I'd rather see agriculture based on the idea of doing what works .
I know, that's stupidly vague, so let me explain.

Reducing pesticide application tends to be good (provided the alternative isn't just surrendering the crop to the insects), but when it's necessary to apply an insecticide, why not choose a less toxic one, even if it happens to be considered synthetic?
(I don't worry about pesticide residues on my food, but I do think pesticide exposure is a real issue for farmworkers .)
Why not use a nitrogen-efficient wheat plant (such a crop is in testing), even if it has a transgene?
The point is, decisions ought to be made based on evidence about how the various options will affect people and the environment.
The debate between organic and conventional is a distraction from that.

Being better for the environment is about more than just the use of chemical pesticides, the typical tag line for this topic.

The aim for organic producers is to reduce the intensity of pests, and to boost plant health so that pests aren't as damaging.
We reduce the intensity of pests by practicing crop rotation - we don't ever plant the same family of crop in the same place two years in a row.
This helps to break the population cycles of the pests involved.
This is most effective with crop diseases and soil borne insects, but there are many flying insects which aren't too bothered about flying across the way to get their favourite snacks.
So we try to balance the nutrients a plant has available to it so that the plant isn't stacked with nitrates, which some research says is what many insects are attracted to.
It's also very plentiful in conventional agriculture due to nitrogen fertilizers, which are very high in nitrates.
The goal is to provide a healthy and nutritious (for humans) plant that is not as attractive to insects.

There is other research that shows that insects are less attracted to vegetables with high sugar content (brix), and building delicious (to humans) vegetables with high brix content makes it less attractive to pests.

An organic farm should also be biodiverse, which means many types of crops planted on one farm, and space left for wildflowers, hedges, verges, and cover crops which really promote beneficial insects.
These are insects that eat other insects, and really aid in diminishing the intensity of pest insects.
Finally there are pests that will eat our crops no matter what steps like those above we take, and we do have strategies for those as well, mainly a physical barrier called 'row cover'.
It's like a very thin fabric blanket that lets light, air and water through, but not insects.
It's a wonderful technology, as it also holds warmth and moisture, and speeds up growth tremendously in the spring and fall, but it can be a pain in the *ss to put out and bring back in.
Also, as Aran Johnson says below, there are organic pesticides available.
What he isn't mentioning is that these are only to be used in extreme circumstances, and they are completely non-persistent in the environment, as they are derived 100% from natural sources.
He is wrong about your produce being covered in them, though, because they are non-persistent, as in they break down in the environment within hours after their application.

However, a farmer like myself, and anyone who would go through all the pains of being certified organic - the manual weeding, the row cover, the crop rotations and cover crops, would and should make every effort to avoid using these types of 'band-aid solutions', certified organic or not.
On the other hand, conventional farmers (and the corporations that supply them) have a strategy to simply kill any insects that come to the crop.
Regardless of how much they are promoting those insects through they're own practices (monocropping, lack of biodiversity, unbalanced soils), the strategy is still the same.
This results in much bigger populations of pest insects, and the ensuing much greater need for pesticides.
It's a vicious cycle, and it's not good for the environment, the farmer, or the consumers.
I would not say that what organic farmers do is perfect, but I think we are heading in the right direction.
I think we need much more research into ways of controlling pests without necessarily killing every insect in the field (as well as the farmers and consumers, eventually!).
The problem with conventional agriculture is that the methodology and the thinking behind it is broken.
It's not going to result in a long term solution without a solid injection of holistic thinking, and that's what organic farming provides.

The main points explaining what Organic and Made with Organic Products are: Produce can be called organic if it’s certified to have grown on soil that had no prohibited substances applied for three years prior to harvest.
Prohibited substances include most synthetic fertilizers and pesticides.

In instances when a grower has to use a synthetic substance to achieve a specific purpose, the substance must first be approved according to criteria that examine its effects on human health and the environment (see other considerations in “Organic 101: Allowed and Prohibited Substances”).As for organic meat, regulations require that animals are raised in living conditions accommodating their natural behaviors (like the ability to graze on pasture), fed 100% organic feed and forage, and not administered antibiotics or hormones.
When it comes to processed, multi-ingredient foods, the USDA organic standards specify additional considerations.
Regulations prohibit organically processed foods from containing artificial preservatives, colors, or flavors and require that their ingredients are organic, with some minor exceptions.
For example, processed organic foods may contain some approved non-agricultural ingredients, like enzymes in yogurt, pectin in fruit jams, or baking soda in baked goods.
When packaged products indicate they are “made with organic [specific ingredient or food group],” this means they contain at least 70% organically produced ingredients.

The remaining non-organic ingredients are produced without using prohibited practices (genetic engineering, for example) but can include substances that would not otherwise be allowed in 100% organic products.
“Made with organic” products will not bear the USDA organic seal, but, as with all other organic products, must still identify the USDA-accredited certifier.
You can look for the identity of the certifier on a packaged product for verification that the organic product meets USDA’s organic standards.

As with all organic foods, none of it is grown or handled using genetically modified organisms, which the organic standards expressly prohibit (see “Organic 101: What Organic Farming (and Processing) Doesn’t Allow”).

Well, to be frank not much!
Here are some aspects you need to take care of to start a garden of your own: 1.
Right site To start with you need to select an area which gets proper sunlight, has the right kind of soil and is not effected by too much wind.
It is recommended that you choose a terrain which does not allow clogging of water and the soil is good enough to hold moisture and nutrients.
Select the right plant varieties There are certain plants which are prone to disease and pests.
Tomato plant, fo example, falls in this category.
Thus it is recommended that you go for plant varities which are disease resistant.
When you buy the saplings/ seeds check for the “disease resistant” tag.
Choose natural fertilizers The whole point of organic gardening is to use natural fertilizers.
If you use chemical fertilizers, then the plants and its fruits will surely carry chemicals.
You can either use well-rotted animal manure or get organic fertilizers from your nearby store.
But in case the soil is already naturally rich, then it is better not to use any fertilizers and let the vegetable grow in its own.
Do not forget mulching Mulches are materials which are placed on the soil surface to boost the soil's moisture holding capacity as well as improve its quality.
Mulching also inhibits growth of growth of weeds and insulates the soil from extreme weather conditions.
For best results use mulches which are made of organic material, because as it decomposes it adds to the nutrient value of the soil.
Water well and avoid weeds Most of the times, gardens are either over-watered or under-watered.
It is therefore very important that you maintain an optimal supply of water in your garden.

Extremes should always be avoided as over-watering washes away the nutrients from the soil, harming the vegetables' health; under-watering on the other hand can lead to drying away and death of the plant.
Rotate plants In order to help soil replenish its lost nutrients, you should practice plant rotation.
The logic behind this is that if the same vegetable is planted, on the same spot year after year there are high chances for diseases to build up in the soil and consequently in the plant.

Also you need to keep in mind that certain group of plants are affected by the same diseases, for example potatoes and pumpkins, therefore it will be good if you avoid planting these plants in rotation.
Most of all give utmost importance to cleaniness.
Make it a point that your garden is kept clean and unwanted waste is not spilled around it.
Also pay attention to your garden so that you can detect pests and diseases at an early stage.

This is a sustainable system designed to produce the maximum amount of food in a given amount of space.

The NOP creates a set of standards, that in my opinion are problematic.
It then certifies companies to do agricultural inspections of farms to verify they are following the standards set in the NOP.
These are called USDA Accredited Certifying Agents (ASA) (src: USDA Accredited Certifying Agents.)
These are not government agents but companies that are certified by the NOP government officials to do the inspection properly, fill out the proper paperwork, etc.
How do you become an ASA?

You pay to take some classes, pay to take some certification tests, and pay the USDA yearly fees (of course, you'll be taking the test every so often and paying for it every time -- usually done by yet other companies -- FAQ: Becoming a Certifying Agent).
Minimum cost $500.
Now to become a certified farm you pay an ASA to come out and inspect your farm.

They'll tell you where you aren't meeting the NOP standards, help you modify your practices until you do, and eventually, once you've meet all the requirements", they do some regular inspections and you'll be certified NOP organic.
If you do this you can say your are "USDA certified organic".
The NOP standards cover mainly 3 things: 1) what adjuncts you use on your soil, 2) the methods you use on the farm, 3) how you raise your animals.
I am not as familiar with the third as we are vegetarian and don't raise anything but chickens for eggs.
But I am vary familiar with the first two.
Basically you can put anything on your plants (herbicides, pesticides, fungicides) provided it is on the NOP "certified" list.
There is a prohibited list -- things you definitely can't use, and an allowed list -- things you definitely can use and this list has a whole slew of synthetic products.
Some of them are even petroleum based.
Part of the NOP is a set of regulations and how to get a product on the approved list, this takes, time, money, and lobbying unless it's so obvious it can't be disputed -- like elemental sulfur.
However, once a company gets their product on the list, any organic farm can use it without worrying about losing their certification.
